title: White House defends James Comey amid scathing criticism over FBI director’s reopening of Clinton probe so close to election
content:
As Democrats blasted FBI Director James Comey over his decision to reopen the bureau ’ s investigation into Hillary Clinton ’ s private server , the White House insisted Monday that the agency chief was not attempting to sway next week ’ s election .
President Obama “ doesn ’ t believe Director Comey is trying to influence the outcome of an election , ” White House press secretary Josh Earnest said during his daily briefing .
“ He ’ s a man of integrity and character and principle , ” Earnest said of Comey , adding that he would not “ defend or criticize ” Comey ’ s actions .
Earnest ’ s comments came in response to repeated questions over Obama ’ s thoughts about Comey ’ s decision to notify top congressional committees in a letter Friday that the agency had uncovered a trove of new emails during a separate probe into Anthony Weiner ’ s sexting , and would , in effect , reopen the investigation into Clinton ’ s private email server .
Clinton leads by 3 points in first poll after FBI bombshell
The emails presumably came from Weiner ’ s estranged wife , Huma Abedin , a longtime Clinton staffer and ally .
The 40-year-old Abedin “ has complied fully and voluntarily with State Department and law enforcement requests , including sitting for hours-long interviews and providing her work-related and potentially work-related documents , ” her lawyer said .
President Obama stands next to FBI Director James Comey in a 2013 photo . White House Press Secretary Josh Earnest said Obama ‘ doesn ’ t believe Comey is trying to influence the outcome of an election , ’ calling him ‘ a man of integrity and character and principle. ’ ( Charles Dharapak/AP )
Abedin hasn ’ t been contacted yet by the FBI , but will be “ forthcoming and cooperative , ” the lawyer added .
Comey has come under scathing criticism since he released the letter , an action that came just 11 days before the election and reportedly against directives from the Department of Justice , upending an already chaotic presidential race . The Justice Department said later Monday , in a letter to lawmakers , that it would “ dedicate all necessary resources ” to review the new emails in the Clinton case “ as expeditiously as possible . ”
Earnest , meanwhile , added that “ we have no knowledge on why Director Comey ” reopened the probe , saying that the White House “ was not given advance notice ” about the Friday letter .
Earnest said Comey , a Republican whom Obama nominated to lead the FBI in 2013 , was “ somebody who ’ s had a distinguished legal career that was rooted ( in the fact ) that his political views don ’ t interfere with his responsibilities as an attorney or a law enforcement officer . ”
Obama “ continues to have confidence in his ability to do his job , ” Earnest said .
AG Eric Holder assailed Comey for having written a `` vague '' letter to top congressional committees last Friday , just 11 days before the election and reportedly against directives from the Department of Justice . ( Alaina Denean/AP )
FBI to scour 650K emails for Clinton ties in bulging Weiner probe
In a scathing Op-Ed in The Washington Post published earlier Monday , former Attorney General Eric Holder said he was “ deeply concerned ” over Comey ’ s decision to send the “ vague ” letter .
“ That decision was incorrect . It violated long-standing Justice Department policies and tradition , ” Holder wrote . “ The department has a practice of not commenting on ongoing investigations . Indeed , except in exceptional circumstances , the department will not even acknowledge the existence of an investigation . ”
“ The department also has a policy of not taking unnecessary action close in time to Election Day that might influence an election ’ s outcome , ” he wrote . “ These rules have been followed during Republican and Democratic administrations . ”
Holder , who called Comey “ a man of integrity and honor , ” called on him to “ dispel the uncertainty he has created before Election Day . ”
De Blasio says Clinton email probe is 'much ado about nothing '
Rep. Steve Cohen ( D-Tenn. ) went a step further Monday , and called on Comey to resign .
Clinton herself also weighed in , telling a crowd in Kent , Ohio , that “ there is no case here . ”
Later Monday , news emerged that Comey had argued in private that the agency should not disclose that Russia had meddled in the U.S. election , sparking new concerns about his role in the season ’ s politics .
CNBC reported , citing sources , that Comey felt it was too close to the election for the FBI to be a part of any disclosure that Russia had been involved in efforts to affect the voting . The report said “ government insiders are perplexed ” over why Comey would have been concerned about the timing of a statement regarding Russia ’ s meddling but not with the timing of his statement about the reopened Clinton probe .
CNN reported that Comey is standing by his decision to notify Congress about the new emails , and people who know him told the Daily News not to expect the lawman to go anywhere .
FBI Director James Comey notified key congressional committees that he would reopen the case into Hillary Clinton ’ s private email sever . ( Cliff Owen/AP )
“ He ’ s untouchable , ” said a retired FBI supervisor who knows the bureau ’ s director . “ I see him standing strong , and he ’ ll only resign if someone tries to force him to do something he thinks is wrong . ”
Former agents and federal prosecutors said they believe Comey would not have acted without good reason .
“ He is one of the smartest people you will find in the Department of Justice , ” said a former federal prosecutor who has worked under Comey .
“ He did what he did to protect the government and himself , ” the source said , dismissing speculation that Attorney General Loretta Lynch would ask him to resign over allegedly violating Justice Department guidelines .
“ Loretta is not a political person , and I don ’ t think she would execute an order that is political in nature . ”
An FBI director serves a 10-year term and can only be dismissed for committing a crime or serious misconduct . Obama — or Clinton or Donald Trump — could not remove Comey because they disagree with him , but they could make his life miserable . President Bill Clinton forced out then-FBI Director William Sessions in 1993 after he came under a cloud for ethical violations .
Ronald Kessler , author of “ The Secrets of the FBI , ” said he thinks the alleged dispute between Comey and Lynch over the disclosure is fiction .
“ She ( Lynch ) left the email investigation to Comey , and he exercised his discretion , ” Kessler said . “ It is unprecedented for an FBI director to reveal that kind of information , but everything is unprecedented here . ”
content_original:
As Democrats blasted FBI Director James Comey over his decision to reopen the bureau’s investigation into Hillary Clinton’s private server, the White House insisted Monday that the agency chief was not attempting to sway next week’s election.

President Obama “doesn’t believe Director Comey is trying to influence the outcome of an election,” White House press secretary Josh Earnest said during his daily briefing.

“He’s a man of integrity and character and principle,” Earnest said of Comey, adding that he would not “defend or criticize” Comey’s actions.

Earnest’s comments came in response to repeated questions over Obama’s thoughts about Comey’s decision to notify top congressional committees in a letter Friday that the agency had uncovered a trove of new emails during a separate probe into Anthony Weiner’s sexting, and would, in effect, reopen the investigation into Clinton’s private email server.

Clinton leads by 3 points in first poll after FBI bombshell

The emails presumably came from Weiner’s estranged wife, Huma Abedin, a longtime Clinton staffer and ally.

The 40-year-old Abedin “has complied fully and voluntarily with State Department and law enforcement requests, including sitting for hours-long interviews and providing her work-related and potentially work-related documents,” her lawyer said.

President Obama stands next to FBI Director James Comey in a 2013 photo. White House Press Secretary Josh Earnest said Obama ‘doesn’t believe Comey is trying to influence the outcome of an election,’ calling him ‘a man of integrity and character and principle.’ (Charles Dharapak/AP)

Abedin hasn’t been contacted yet by the FBI, but will be “forthcoming and cooperative,” the lawyer added.

Comey has come under scathing criticism since he released the letter, an action that came just 11 days before the election and reportedly against directives from the Department of Justice, upending an already chaotic presidential race. The Justice Department said later Monday, in a letter to lawmakers, that it would “dedicate all necessary resources” to review the new emails in the Clinton case “as expeditiously as possible.”

FBI mad bomber James Comey needs to resign

Earnest, meanwhile, added that “we have no knowledge on why Director Comey” reopened the probe, saying that the White House “was not given advance notice” about the Friday letter.

Earnest said Comey, a Republican whom Obama nominated to lead the FBI in 2013, was “somebody who’s had a distinguished legal career that was rooted (in the fact) that his political views don’t interfere with his responsibilities as an attorney or a law enforcement officer.”

Obama “continues to have confidence in his ability to do his job,” Earnest said.

AG Eric Holder assailed Comey for having written a "vague" letter to top congressional committees last Friday, just 11 days before the election and reportedly against directives from the Department of Justice. (Alaina Denean/AP)

Other prominent Democrats were less diplomatic.

FBI to scour 650K emails for Clinton ties in bulging Weiner probe

In a scathing Op-Ed in The Washington Post published earlier Monday, former Attorney General Eric Holder said he was “deeply concerned” over Comey’s decision to send the “vague” letter.

“That decision was incorrect. It violated long-standing Justice Department policies and tradition,” Holder wrote. “The department has a practice of not commenting on ongoing investigations. Indeed, except in exceptional circumstances, the department will not even acknowledge the existence of an investigation.”

“The department also has a policy of not taking unnecessary action close in time to Election Day that might influence an election’s outcome,” he wrote. “These rules have been followed during Republican and Democratic administrations.”

Holder, who called Comey “a man of integrity and honor,” called on him to “dispel the uncertainty he has created before Election Day.”

De Blasio says Clinton email probe is 'much ado about nothing'

Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign

Rep. Steve Cohen (D-Tenn.) went a step further Monday, and called on Comey to resign.

Clinton herself also weighed in, telling a crowd in Kent, Ohio, that “there is no case here.”

Later Monday, news emerged that Comey had argued in private that the agency should not disclose that Russia had meddled in the U.S. election, sparking new concerns about his role in the season’s politics.

CNBC reported, citing sources, that Comey felt it was too close to the election for the FBI to be a part of any disclosure that Russia had been involved in efforts to affect the voting. The report said “government insiders are perplexed” over why Comey would have been concerned about the timing of a statement regarding Russia’s meddling but not with the timing of his statement about the reopened Clinton probe.

CNN reported that Comey is standing by his decision to notify Congress about the new emails, and people who know him told the Daily News not to expect the lawman to go anywhere.

FBI Director James Comey notified key congressional committees that he would reopen the case into Hillary Clinton’s private email sever. (Cliff Owen/AP)

“He’s untouchable,” said a retired FBI supervisor who knows the bureau’s director. “I see him standing strong, and he’ll only resign if someone tries to force him to do something he thinks is wrong.”

Former agents and federal prosecutors said they believe Comey would not have acted without good reason.

“He is one of the smartest people you will find in the Department of Justice,” said a former federal prosecutor who has worked under Comey.

“He did what he did to protect the government and himself,” the source said, dismissing speculation that Attorney General Loretta Lynch would ask him to resign over allegedly violating Justice Department guidelines.

“Loretta is not a political person, and I don’t think she would execute an order that is political in nature.”

An FBI director serves a 10-year term and can only be dismissed for committing a crime or serious misconduct. Obama — or Clinton or Donald Trump — could not remove Comey because they disagree with him, but they could make his life miserable. President Bill Clinton forced out then-FBI Director William Sessions in 1993 after he came under a cloud for ethical violations.

Ronald Kessler, author of “The Secrets of the FBI,” said he thinks the alleged dispute between Comey and Lynch over the disclosure is fiction.

“She (Lynch) left the email investigation to Comey, and he exercised his discretion,” Kessler said. “It is unprecedented for an FBI director to reveal that kind of information, but everything is unprecedented here.”
